Role of oxygen vacancy in cobalt doped ceria catalyst for styrene epoxidation using molecular oxygen Shahid Hassan a Rawesh Kumar b Ankur Tiwari a Weiyi Song c Lennart van Haandel d Jai Krishna Pandey e Emiel Hensen c ⁎ Biswajit Chowdhury a ⁎ a Department of Applied Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology (ISM), Dhanbad, Jharkhand, India Department of Applied Chemistry Indian Institute of Technology (ISM) Dhanbad Jharkhand India b Department of Chemistry, NIT, Jamshedpur, India Department of Chemistry NIT Jamshedpur India c State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum, 18#, Fuxue Road, Chang Ping, Beijing 102249, China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing China University of Petroleum 18#, Fuxue Road Chang Ping Beijing 102249 China d Laboratory of Inorganic Materials Chemistry, Schuit Institute of Catalysis, PO Box 5 13, 5600 MB, Eindhoven, The Netherlands Laboratory of Inorganic Materials Chemistry Schuit Institute of Catalysis PO Box 5 13 Eindhoven MB 5600 The Netherlands e Central Institute of Mining and Fuel Research (CIMFR), Dhanbad, India Central Institute of Mining and Fuel Research (CIMFR) Dhanbad India ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract The oxygen vacancy formation and refillment of oxygen vacancy by molecular oxygen are the key steps of catalyst redox cycle towards styrene epoxidation reaction. Well dispersed, Isomorphically substituted and energetically favorable cobalt based redox cycle in ceria lattice caused lower oxygen formation energy, oxygen adsorption energy and activation energy than pure ceria for the reaction ensuring excellent catalytic activity. DFT studies show that inclusion of cobalt in ceria leads to lower the oxygen removal energy. Oxygen vacancy formation resulted into the rise of the spin magnetic moment of cobalt to 2.70 μB indicating reduction of Co+3 to Co+2 as well as fall of oxygen adsorption energy. A mechanistic proposal is presented in which Co3+/Co2+, Ce4+/Ce3+, oxygen vacancies are involved in adsorption, activation reaction of oxygen and styrene on the surface of the catalyst. The Co(4)-CeO2 catalyst also demonstrated reactivity towards stilbene, cyclooctene under similar reaction condition. The catalyst was regenerated up to three cycles. Keywords Oxygen vacancy Cobalt Ceria Styrene epoxidation 1 Introduction Formation of the oxygen vacancy during the active oxygen supply from catalyst surface to the substrate and subsequent refillment of oxygen vacancy by oxidant/molecular oxygen/air are the key steps of catalytic cycle for an oxidation reaction [1]. In the former step catalyst is reduced and substrate is oxidized while in later step reduced catalyst is re-oxidized. The density functional theory (DFT) calculation showed that among many redox couple CeO2/Ce2O3, TiO2/Ti2O3, V2O5/VO2/V2O3 and MoO3/MoO2; CeO2/Ce2O3 have least reduction energy of CeO2/Ce2O3 couple about 0.2 eV compared to others [2]. The high oxygen storage capacity of ceria along with quick switching of Ce4+/Ce3+ redox cycle [3–5] had brought most of the attention of catalyst community for an oxidation reaction [6–8]. Further, doping of lower valent cations in ceria is a common strategy for tuning reducibility and the oxygen storage capacity of the ceria which increases its catalytic performance at low temperature [9,10] due to lattice contraction-exapansion [11] and electron deficit centre [12]. If both the dopant and the support have enriched redox chemistry, oxygen vacancy can be formed by reduction of support or dopant or both. Several catalysts were reported for styrene epoxidation reaction using conventional oxidant such as H2O2 or TBHP Among different homogeneous complexes 12-molybdophosphoric acid [13], oxovanadium complexes [14,15], vanadium doped catalysts [16,17], manganese porphyrin [18], manganese salen complex [19], and manganese schiff bases [20], were found more effective for styrene epoxidation reaction. In the case of heterogeneous catalysts there are wide reports in the literature. Several iron based catalysts [21–25], titanosilicates [26,27], gold or gold nanoparticle deposited titanosilicates [28–32] and lanthanum containing catalysts [33] were reported as a good catalyst for styrene epoxidation reaction.,The oxidation reaction using molecular oxygen is the atom efficient pathway to get styrene epoxide from styrene. The silver, yttrium, copper containg catalyst were very much active for styrene epoxidation reaction using molecular oxygen [34–37]. Apart from those Mg or Co, Al containing binary layered double hydroxides [38,39], cobalt doped catalyst systems [40–48], were used effectively in styrene epoxidation reaction. Although, there are many reports dealing with ceria as the support for oxidation reaction [49–51], there are relatively few works focusing on the role of the oxygen vacancy (Ov) in doped ceria lattice for an epoxidation reaction using molecular oxygen as an oxidant [52–54]. As cobalt based catalyst system [54–56] was found more promising than other catalyst system [5] for the epoxidation of various olefins, in the present study we have selected cobalt as a dopant in the ceria lattice for styrene oxidation using molecular oxygen as an oxidant. It is hypothesized that the creation of oxygen vacancy by doping of cobalt in the CeO2 lattice will facilitate adsorption of molecular oxygen in the CoxCe1-xO2 (111) surface rendering activation of molecular oxygen for enhancing the catalytic activity towards styrene epoxidation reaction. To proceed for establishing the hypothesis CeO2, Co(4)-CeO2 (Co = 4 mol%), Co(8)-CeO2 (Co = 8 mol%) and Co(12)-CeO2 (Co = 12 mol%) were prepared and investigated for styrene epoxidation reaction at atmospheric condition. The most active catalyst in terms of productivity was characterized by XRD, N2 physisorption, FESEM, HRTEM, XPS and TPR techniques. The activity of Co(4)-CeO2 (Co = 4 mol%) was further optimized by varying solvent, the temperature and the oxygen flow. Interesting correlation could be drawn from the catalytic activity, catalyst characterization and theoretical studies demonstrating the role of oxygen vacancy towards styrene epoxidation reaction. 2 Experimental procedure 2.1 Chemicals and reagents Cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (99.9%)) was obtained from Sigma-Aldrich and used without further purification. Triethanolamine (TEA, 99%), cobalt nitrate hexahydrate(Co(NO3)3·6H2O) were supplied by Acros Organics and Tetraethylammonium hydroxide (TEAOH, 20% aqueous solution) was obtained from Merck Germany. All solutions were prepared using milli-Qwater (resistivity 18.2 MΩ × cm). 2.2 Preparation of cobalt doped CeO2 Cobalt doped cerium oxide was prepared by a non-hydrothermal sol–gel method as described in our previous work [8]. In this procedure, a solution of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (99.9%, Aldrich) was added to a mixture of triethanolamine (TEA, 99%, Acros Organics) and water under stirring at the room temperature. After complete addition of the cerium nitrate solution, cobalt nitrate hexahydrate was added in solid form to the solution under constant stirring. The mixture was stirred for 10 min after which tetraethylammonium hydroxide (TEAOH, 20% aqueous solution, Merck Germany) was added dropwise under constant stirring resulting gel wih the molar composition TEA: Ce(NO3)3·6H2O:H2O: Co(NO3)3·6H2O: TEAOH = 0.2:0.1:1.1:(0.004-0.008-0.012): 0.1. This mixture was kept for 24 h under continuous stirring at room temperature. The prepared gel was dried at 383 K for 24hin a static air oven. Finally, the dried material was collected and calcined at 973 K for 10 h with a heating rate of 1 °C min−1in a muffle furnace (Thermocraft USA). 2.3 Catalyst characterization The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured at liquid nitrogen temperature (77 K) with a QuantachromeNova-3200e. The samples were outgassed at 573 K for 6 h. The surface area was determined by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation. The average pore size distributions were calculated using the BJH (Barrett – Joyner – Halenda) model. XRD characterization was done in an X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku, Ultima IV) using Cu Kα radiation as the X-ray source (40 kV, 20 mA). The peaks were identified by a search and match technique using X’PertHighScore Plus software and the JCPDS database. The average CeO2 crystallite size was estimated from the (111) diffraction peak at 2θ ∼ 28.6° using the Scherrer equation. Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) was carried out using a field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM Supra 55, Carl Zeiss, Germany) equipped with an energy dispersive spectrometer (Oxford Liquid Nitrogen free SDD X MAX 50 EDS) detector. The HRTEM investigation was done on JEOL JEM 2100 microscope operated at 200 KV acceleration voltage using Lacey carbon coated Cu grid of 300 mesh size. The TPR profile of the samples was recorded with Chemisorb 2750 (Micrometrics, USA) instrument equipped with a TCD detector. The TPR experiments were carried out by reducing the catalyst samples using a gas mixture of 10% H2 in Ar with a flow rate of 20 mL/min. The temperature was increased from ambient temperature to 973 K at a rate of 10 K min−1 under a flow of 10% H2 in Ar and the hydrogen consumption was monitored by observing the change in the TCD signal. XPS measurements were carried out with a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha, equipped with a monochromatic small-spot X-ray source and a 180° double focusing hemispherical analyzer with a 128-channel detector. Spectra were obtained using an aluminium anode (Al Kα = 1486.6 eV) operating at 72W and a spot size of 400 μm. Survey scans were measured at a constant pass energy of 200 eV and region scans at 50 eV. The background pressure was 2 × 10−9 mbar and during measurement 3 × 10−7 mbar argon because of the charge compensation dual beam source. The fraction of Ce3+/Ce4+ in the samples was calculated from the peak areas. 3 Styrene epoxidation reaction The catalytic activity of the catalyst for styrene epoxidation reaction was carried out in 50 cm3 two necked round bottle fitted with reflux condenser and oxygen nozzle under atmospheric pressure at 373 K for 4 h under 600 rpm agitation speed. Properly dried 0.2 g catalyst (30–60 μm mesh size) was added to mixture of 10 mmol styrene (Acros Organic), 20 mL DMF (99.8%, Merck, India) as solvent and 0.2 mL dodecane (99%, Acros Organics) as internal standard in round bottle. Then oxygen was bubbled in the reaction mixture through the nozzle at a flow rate of 50 cm3min−1. The products were analyzed by gas chromatography (CIC-India Model No 2010) using a SE-30 column and an FID detector. The details of the GC analysis conditions are given in the supporting information. The separated catalyst was washed with acetone (4–5 times), dried at 353 K overnight in air, and used again in recycle experiments. The TOF was calculated on the basis of mole of styrene converted per mole of cobalt. 3.1 DFT calculation To investigate the role of oxygen vacancies towards the styrene epoxidation reaction, DFT calculation has been done on the most stable (111) termination of CoxCe1-xO2 surface. The stabilization energy of the cobalt doped ceria was measured by changing the number of oxygen vacancies on the doped oxides. The energy of adsorption of oxygen molecule to the vacant site of doped oxide has also been calculated theoretically. Finally, reaction energy was calculated for clean ceria surface and doped ceria surface considering the styrene molecule as well as adsorbed oxygen molecule. 4 Results 4.1 Preliminary catalytic activity results The catalytic activities of CeO2 and differently cobalt loaded Co-CeO2 catalyst for styrene epoxidation reaction using molecular O2 was evaluated and presented in Table 1 . The pure CeO2 was almost inert in the reaction whereas cobalt doped CeO2 showed high catalytic activity towards the styrene epoxidation reaction using molecular oxygen as an oxidant. On increasing the cobalt loading from 4 to 12 mol%, a decrease in styrene conversion (i.e. 26.31-19.41%) and styrene oxide selectivity (i.e. 57.29-47.50%) is observed. To investigate the physicochemical properties, the best catalyst Co(4)-CeO2 was characterized by XRD, N2-physisorption, XPS, HRTEM and TPR techniques. Further to investigate the role of oxygen vacancies towards the styrene epoxidation reaction, DFT study has been carried out on the most stable (111) termination of CoxCe1-xO2 surface. 4.2 Characterization results The X-ray diffraction patterns and semi quantitative analysis of CeO2 and Co-doped CeO2 are presented in Fig. 1 and Table 2 respectively. The peaks in the diffractograms belong to the cubic fluorite structure (Space Group: Fm3m, JCPDS no. 00-006-0416) of CeO2. The absence of cobalt oxide diffraction peaks suggests high dispersion of sub nanometer level cobalt oxide species in the ceria matrix forming solid solution as found earlier in our studies [57]. It is observed that ceria particles of Co(4)-CeO2 had smaller crystallite size and cell parameter than CeO2. The decrease in crystallite size may be due to decrease in surface hydroxyl as lower valent cobalt replaces higher valent ceria [3]. As the cobalt cations have smaller ionic radii (Co2+: 0.075 nm and Co3+: 0.061 nm) compared to Ce4+ cations (0.097 nm), a lattice contraction is evident in the cobalt doped ceria sample [58]. Thus, the decrease in the unit cell parameter suggests that cobalt is incorporated in the ceria lattice. The textural features of cobalt doped CeO2 catalysts have been investigated by surface area and porosity measurements. The adsorption-desorption isotherms and textural characteristics CeO2 and Co-CeO2 catalysts as obtained from N2 physisorption studies are depicted in Fig. 2 and Table 2. The catalysts were characterized by the presence of a hysteresis loop indicating mesoporous nature of catalyst [58]. The hysteresis loop of CeO2 is determined by limiting adsorption at high P/Po whereas Co doped ceria do not exhibits any limiting adsorption at high P/Po. The non-limiting adsorption at high P/Po after Co doping indicates either non-rigid aggregates of plate like particle or assemblages of slit-shaped pores [59]. It is observed that the textural property varies widely after Co incorporation in comparison with the CeO2 prepared by same procedure. The surface area, pore volume and average pore diameter were increased in the presence of cobalt which might be due to controlled hydrolysis of respective metal precursors and further condensation among polymeric complex of Ce and Co ions in presence of triethanolamine polyfunctional ligand during sol-gel synthesis [7]. The particle size for Co(4)-CeO2 catalyst was determined by HRTEM analysis which is shown in Fig. 3 (a, b). It is found that particle sizes range from 20 to 40 nm which resembles to the crystallite size obtained from XRD analysis. The lattice fringes due to (200), (111) and (220) planes of ceria phase are found in the HRTEM image. As observed in Fig. 3(c) the SAED pattern confirms the high crystallinity of the Co(4)-CeO2 catalyst. The Ce (3d), Co (2p3/2) and O (1s) core-level XPS spectra are shown in Fig. 4 . The core-level binding energies of Ce (3d) spectra were fitted with five spin-orbit doublets associated with Ce3+ and Ce4+ contributions [60] (Fig. 4(a)) and the numerical data are listed in Table 3 . The peaks labeled as u, uo, u′, u″ and u‴ are corresponds to 3d3/2 spin-orbit states, and those labeled v, vo, v′, v″ and v‴ are correspond to 3d5/2 states (Fig. 4(a)). Furthermore, in accordance with literature components v and u were fitted with two contributions (a and b), with fixed area ratios to take into account asymmetry [61,62]. Among all levels, the components vo, v′, uo and u′ are attributed to Ce3+ as present in Ce2O3 and components v, v″, v‴, u, u″ and u‴ are attributed to Ce4+ as present in CeO2 lattice. The components v(u) and v″(u″) arise from the hybridization of Ce (4f) orbitals with O (2p) molecular orbitals in the valence band [57]. The peaks at v‴ and u‴ are ascribed to a 4f° configuration of CeO2 [60]. The peaks at vo (uo) and v′ (u′) are ascribed to photoemission from Ce cations of Ce2O3. The presence of Ce3+ is found at 880.5 eV and 885.7 eV as indicated by the dotted lines vo and v′. The XPS spectra for Co (2p3/2) core electrons (Fig. 4(b)) were rather broad and consisted of one main peak (779.9 eV) and a weak satellite feature (785.0 eV). The binding energy and weak satellite feature suggest that Co is most likely present as Co3O4 [63], along with the presence of CoO species. The metallic Co, which should be located at ∼778 eV, is not found in the XPS profile [64]. To know the nature of M-O-M′ bond the O (1s) spectra were recorded and depicted in (Fig. 4(c)). Three peaks can be observed in the spectrum, a major peak at 529 eV and two minor peaks at 530.7 eV and 532.4 eV binding energies. The dominant peak at 529 eV is assigned to oxygen in the lattice of CeO2, one minor peak at 530.9 eV due to oxygen likely as in OH and another minor peak at 532.4 eV due to oxygen of possible adsorb water [8,65]. For the Co loaded ceria, the O (1s) peak is mostly symmetrical which indicates the cobalt is highly dispersed over the ceria matrix. To investigate the temperature dependence of the redox properties of Co-CeO2 catalyst, temperature programmed reduction (TPR) was carried out for cobalt loaded sample as well as CeO2 support (as shown in Fig. 5 ). For pure CeO2 the peak near 673 K can be attributed to reduction of surface CeO2 species. The peak at high temperature, i.e. at 1073 K is due to reduction of bulk CeO2 [66]. However, for Co-CeO2 sample, the surface reduction of CeO2 occurred at a lower temperature, near 523 K. The reduction temperature of bulk CeO2 did not change significantly after cobalt doping. As reported in the literature, the reduction of cobalt species occurred in two steps. At first, Co3O4 reduced to CoO, and then CoO reduced to Co [46]. The Co doped ceria catalyst showed the first phase of Co oxide reduction at around 623 K. The additional peak at 873 K For the Co(4)-CeO2 can be explained in terms of increased interaction between CoO and CeO2 species in Co(4)-CeO2. For the Co(4)-CeO2 catalyst CeO2 species reduced to Ce2O3 species easily. It may be easily concluded from the Ce (3d) core electron binding energy and TPR profile that many Co species were oxidized back to CoO in a combined redox process. The reduction of CoO, lead to that exceptional increase in reduction temperature of CoO. It is clear from the reduction profiles and hydrogen uptake that the Co(4)-CeO2 catalyst has higher hydrogen uptake at low temperature range. 4.3 Improvement of catalytic activity The activity of Co(4)-CeO2 catalyst was optimized by varying the solvents, the reaction temperature and the oxygen flow. Among all tested solvents, DMF was found best towards epoxidation reaction (Table 4 , Entry 1–4). As reported in the literature [46] cobalt exists in a tetrahedral co-ordination environment and it may form a true active sites for the reaction to occur. The DMF solvent were very effective due to tetrahedral coordination with Co as well as an oxygen transfer agent [39,43,44,46]. Therefore, interaction of the DMF with the catalytic sites and styrene molecule favour the formation of styrene epoxide. However, a certain amount of styrene conversion was obtained in cyclohexanone and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) solvent where the epoxide selectivity was lower and benzaldehyde obtained as major product. To check the effect of co-ordination of solvent with metal in the reaction medium, a non co-ordinating solvent decane was also used. No reaction took place when decane was used as solvent. So, it can be concluded that DMF is the best solvent for styrene epoxidation reaction using cobalt based catalytic system. It is observed that conversion of styrene is increased sharply from 10.64% to 89.09% with the increase of reaction temperature from 353 K to 413 K (Table 4, Entry 5–8) [47]. Being triplet molecular oxygen in ground state is non-reactive toward organic molecules at low temperatures. Either reaction of triplet dioxygen with the singlet state organic substrates to give the excited triplet state oxygenated product or reaction of excited singlet dioxygen with single state organic substrate is spin-allowed at high temperature [67]. The higher catalytic activity at higher reaction temperature can be also explained as at increasing reaction temperature, the rates of surface reactions will be more rapid than the rates of diffusion. The styrene conversion is increased from 73.48% to 99% with increase of O2 flow rate from 5 to 20 mL/min (Table 4, Entry 9–12). It can be said that there are dual sites in the catalyst surface; one is for styrene adsorption another is for oxygen adsorption. At higher flow rate (>20 mL/min), the styrene conversion is decreased due to coverage of styrene adsorption sites by molecular oxygen. Overall, it is found that high molecular O2 flow rate i.e. 20 mL/min, reaction temperature 413 K, solvent DMF and 4 h reaction duration is the optimum parameter to get best catalytic activity for this reaction having >99% styrene conversion, >90% styrene oxide selectivity and productivity 9.8 × 10−4 Kmol/KgCat/s. The catalyst recyclability is one of the important parameter to commercialize the catalyst. In the present study cobalt doped CeO2 catalyst emerged as a highly recyclable catalyst. The catalytic activity of the catalysts remained almost unaffected up to three cycles (Table 4, Entry 13–15). The marginal decrease is observed in the styrene oxide selectivity rather than styrene oxide conversion. This suggests that stability of this catalyst is good enough for long run operation in the present reaction condition. In addition, the Co(4)-CeO2 catalyst induced several epoxidation reactions with different substrate e.g. Cyclooctene, Stilbene (Table 4, Entry 16–17). The catalytic activity results show that excellent selectivity towards corresponding epoxide is obtained. From the UV, EDX, and XRD analyses of used and fresh catalyst, it has been found that the co-ordination sites of Co in Co(4)-CeO2 catalyst are preserved, the ceria phase is retained and the Co% is reduced marginally after the reaction respectively (Fig. S1–S4). The catalytic performance (conversion, selectivity, TOF and productivity) of Co(4)-CeO2 catalyst was compared with that of previously reported catalysts [68,69] for styrene epoxidation reaction (Table 5 ). It seems that Co(4)-CeO2 superior when parameters are compared together. It is to be noted that rigorous comparison of catalysts in terms of TOF is not possible because all the catalysts are not in the surface controlled regime. The catalyst kinetic calculation shows that there is no gas-solid, liquid-solid and intrapore mass transfer limitations for Co(4)-CeO2 catalyst. 4.4 DFT results The oxygen vacancy formation energy (E f ) of doped ceria catalyst was computed according to the following equation [70]. E f  = E (Ce1-xMxO2-δ) + ½ E(O2) − E(Ce1-xMxO2) E(Ce1-xMxO2) is energy of the bulk Ce1-xMxO2, E(O2) is energy of O2 in gas phase and E (Ce1-xMxO2-δ) is energy of the bulk in the presence of one oxygen vacancy. Again after the vacancy formation, the change in oxidation state of metal (reduction of metal cation) can be noticed by change in spin magnetic moment of cations. The optimized structure of CoxCe1-xO2 is shown in Fig. 6 a–c. The Co atom coordinates to three oxygen atoms. The spin magnetic moment of cobalt is 0.12 μB and spin magnetic moment of oxygen is 0.15 μB. This implies that oxygen atoms are closer to cobalt and cobalt is in +3 oxidation state. The addition of cobalt lead to lower oxygen removal energy, in fact oxygen will be easily removed at ambient condition. The energy of oxygen vacancy formation is −2.19 eV which is much lower than oxygen vacancy formation energy in clean CeO2 surface having oxygen vacancy formation energy 2.11 eV. It has been reported in literature that doping of lower valent metal lowers the oxygen vacancy formation energy in ceria [71]. The relationship between crystallographic axis and channel direction control the reactivity of mesoporous ceria [72]. It is found in our study that when one oxygen vacancy is formed spin magnetic moment of cobalt is increased to 2.70 μB which implied cobalt is reduced to Co+2 state. However, while two oxygen vacancies are formed then two Ce+3 is generated which is not energetically favorable as oxygen vacancy formation energy is +1.28 eV. So it can be said that one Ov will be the stable state in cobalt-ceria solid solution and oxygen can be easily removed in ambient conditions and sur face will be reach with oxygen vacancies. The energy of adsorption of oxygen to cobalt doped ceria surface is important to justify the role of cobalt doping on the ceria surface. The energy of adsorption of oxygen molecule to the CoxCe(1-x)O2 surface having one oxygen vacancy is found −0.3 eV which implies adsorption is exothermic in nature. The oxygen adsorption energy is much lower than reported for MnxCe(1-x)O2 (111) surface [73]. This establishes the fact that oxygen can be easily adsorb in the oxygen vacant site of CoxCe(1-x)O2 with one Ov. The DFT calculation has been done on the transition state of styrene adsorbed on clean ceria surface as well as defective ceria surface. Interestingly it is found that reaction energy as well as activation energy is higher for styrene reacts with lattice oxygen of ceria in comparison with styrene reacts with adsorbed O2 in the vacant sites of CoxCe1-xO2 surface. 5 Discussion As per the electron pair Lewis theory of a chemical bond, removing oxygen atom from the surface creates oxygen vacancy which is Lewis base [74]. As the Ce4+ species are Lewis acids, the oxygen vacancy formation is promoted by a strong acid-base interaction. The unpaired electrons created during oxygen vacancy formation occupy the Ce (3d) orbital and reduce it to Ce3+ [12]. As reported in the literature, an oxygen vacancy formation is accomplished by the reduction of two Ce4+ ions to two Ce3+ [75]. After cobalt loading, the cobalt oxide covers the ceria surface which is found from Co(2p)/Ce(3d) binding energy ratio (supporting information, Table S1). The surface concentration of sample Co(4)-CeO2 is close to the bulk Co/Ce ratio which indicates that cobalt is highly dispersed might be in the form of nanoclustures. The XPS result shows that isomorphic substitution of Ce4+ by doped metal occurred in Co(4)-CeO2. From the DFT study it is found that one oxygen vacant site created due to reduction of Co+3 to Co+2 is energetically more stable in comparison two oxygen vacant sites. The presence of Co+2 species has been observed in the XPS results described earlier. Highly dispersed Co is believed to be entirely interacting with CeO2 where the enrichment of ceria species was claimed favorable for O2 activation [49]. Panda et al. reported the preparation of cobalt impregnated ceria nanowire and showed catalytic activity for styrene epoxidation reaction using molecular oxygen [76]. The selectivity towards styrene epoxides was less and decreased with time. The asymmetrical O (1s) XPS for the cobalt doped ceria in their work resembles with the literature report by Reddy et al. [77]. The nature of oxygen vacancy is different in the Co-CeO2 catalyst in present study as evidenced by XPS measurement and DFT calculation which was described earlier. 6 Mechanistic proposal Activation of O2 into superoxo radical at DMF assisted Co+2 sites and thereafter oxidative addition of oxygen to CC is widely accepted for Cobalt based catalyst system towards styrene epoxidation reaction [44,48,78]. Co doped ceria catalyst is seemed to bring some new insights towards reaction mechanism due to quick redox cycle of Ce+4/Ce+3 along with Co+3/Co+2 redox cycle, subsequent oxygen vacancy formation as well as its replenishment by some oxygen source i.e. molecular oxygen [4]. Based on the literature survey, current experimental results, and DFT studies it can be said that cobalt covers the ceria surface and lead to lower oxygen removal energy, in fact oxygen is easily removed at ambient condition [71]. During oxygen removal, the active oxygen is supplied from the catalyst surface to the substrate styrene and carried out one set of epoxidation reaction. As DMF has a higher oxygen-dissolving capacity, molecular O2 is easily available to the catalyst surface due to easy mass transfer and very soon it is adsorbed on the defective oxygen vacancy as shown in Figs. 7 and 8 . The excess electrons which were localized on Co and Ce atoms transferred to the O2 molecule which activates it effectively. The electrophilic O2 2− species attacks the electron rich double bond of styrene and donates one oxygen atom to styrene for carried out another one set of epoxidation reaction. The remaining O2− portion of the species gets incorporated into the catalyst lattice. In the present case highly dispersed Co2+, oxygen vacancy and Ce3+ species form ensemble sites which result high productivity towards styrene epoxidation reaction using molecular oxygen. 7 Conclusion In conclusion, redox sites enriched cobalt doped mesoporous ceria was prepared using non hydrothermal sol gel method. The catalyst is specified by isomorphic substitution of Ce+4 by Co+3, high dispersion of sub nanometer level cobalt oxide and energically favorable cobalt redox cycle for one oxygen vacant sites. All together cause lower reaction energy and activation energy for styrene epoxidation reaction over cobalt doped ceria catalyst than pure ceria. The Co(4)-CeO2 catalyst (Co/Ce = 4/100) showed >99% styrene conversion, >90% styrene selectivity and high productivity 9.8 × 10−4 Kmol/KgCat/s in DMF solvent at 20 mL/min O2 flow rate, 413 K reaction temperature during 4 h reaction. This catalyst is highly recyclable and cable of epoxidation reaction with other olefins i.e. cyclooctene and stilbene. Acknowledgements SH would like to acknowledge UGC for research fellowship. coredata.dc:description: The oxygen vacancy formation and refillment of oxygen vacancy by molecular oxygen are the key steps of catalyst redox cycle towards styrene epoxidation reaction. Well dispersed, Isomorphically substituted and energetically favorable cobalt based redox cycle in ceria lattice caused lower oxygen formation energy, oxygen adsorption energy and activation energy than pure ceria for the reaction ensuring excellent catalytic activity. DFT studies show that inclusion of cobalt in ceria leads to lower the oxygen removal energy. Oxygen vacancy formation resulted into the rise of the spin magnetic moment of cobalt to 2.70 μB indicating reduction of Co+3 to Co+2 as well as fall of oxygen adsorption energy. A mechanistic proposal is presented in which Co3+/Co2+, Ce4+/Ce3+, oxygen vacancies are involved in adsorption, activation reaction of oxygen and styrene on the surface of the catalyst. The Co(4)-CeO2 catalyst also demonstrated reactivity towards stilbene, cyclooctene under similar reaction condition. The catalyst was regenerated up to three cycles.
coredata.dc:title: Role of oxygen vacancy in cobalt doped ceria catalyst for styrene epoxidation using molecular oxygen
coredata.prism:issueName: Metal Oxides in Catalysis - Professor Benjaram M. Reddy Festschrift
